Comment: One of the better games I've played. White opens with 1 e4, and a Sicilian defence ensues...

White now provides cover for his e4 pawn, while opening the rank for a Kingside castle.
Black responds with a suggestion of a fiancetto with his black-squared Bishop
While Black's Queenside may appear weakened, he has succeeded in bringing two pawns in direct approach to the centre.
While Black's Queenside may appear weakened, he has succeeded in bringing two pawns in direct approach to the centre.
White correctly pins the f6 Knight, however it is easily defended, and retreat is forced. Black succeeds in gaining a development move without reply.

Black capitalizes by forcing a weakening of White's defences, should he choose to castle; with the only sensible response being 11 f3 (since White does not wish to weaken his e4 pawn by removing part of it's defence), Black has succeeded in controlling the order of his opponent's moves, and hinders development of White's Queen in the process.

This move may have been White's weakest point. Black clearly controls the game at this point, with the following move being obvious to most. Further, White has removed his c3 Knight's defence.

Another forced move. Further, White's castling options are reduced to tatters.
Another forced move. Further, White's castling options are reduced to tatters.
A clever move from White. Black concedes a pawn, however was this gambit part of the plan?
A clever move from White. Black concedes a pawn, however was this gambit part of the plan?

At this stage, Black looks desperate. At a glance, his position looks weak. It appears he has returned control to White with the loss of a pawn in the process. His Queenside pawns appear ragged and his Queen appears to be too enclosed to make an impact. He has yet to develop his King's Bishop, which appeared to be part of his plan earlier. Has he lost the plot, or is White bringing the game to Black?

Correctly again, White prevents the imminent check, preventing another forced move.
Black now develops his Bishop, consolidating his weak side.
Inevitable though it is, 17 b4 forces Black to move his Bishop. However, Black can retain centre position, and the slim advantage it now provides.
With his white-squared Bishop poised, this appears to be the appropriate move, but can White afford to lose his pawn on a2?
